mentions.context: SpecAug is primarily designed for spectrograms or MFBs.

SpecAug [65]: This feature-level augmentation method randomly modifies the filter-bank features by (i) warping along the time axis, (ii) time masking, and (iii) frequency masking along random time-frequency locations.

The Voicebox tool [7] is used to randomly apply one of the three speech enhancement algorithms to the utterances: spectral subtraction [4], log MMSE noise estimation based enhancement [27], and de-reverberation [20].
Using the SoX library, 3 we randomly convert the utterances in different lossy codecs, such as .aac,
We do this by applying SpecAug directly on the MFBs that are generated as an intermediate stage during MFCC extraction.
In this work, we utilize SpecAug with MFCCs mainly due to a fair comparison with the baseline and the existing LID literature with the three corpora which used MFCCs.
Due to masking, the standard SpecAug zeros out some of the MFB values, and the remaining values remain the same.
This uses non-speech samples from the MUSAN corpus [80].
However, in this work, we utilize the SpecAug on MFCCs.
For feature-level augmentation, we evaluate SpecAug and mixup separately.
The TDNN architectures are implemented using the PyTorch library [66] of Python.
During the decorrelation by the final DCT stage, SpecAug perturbs the entire feature matrix.
Nevertheless, several earlier works also applied SpecAug on MFCCs [21,72,87,97].
We also cascade two feature-level augmentation techniques, SpecAug, and mixup, independently on top of different signal-level augmentation methods.
We observe that only for some cases during the evaluation with KGPtest data, x-vector shows slightly improved performances.
This augmentation category is followed from [82] and implemented with the Kaldi tool's [68] VoxCeleb recipe 1 .
For simulating the different recording environments, utterances are convolved with randomly chosen room impulse responses from the RIR corpus following the Kaldi tool [68].
